Title: [from] Tortilla Sun
Author: by Jennifer Cervantes
Content: Clang cla-clang, clang clang. The next morning, I found Mom in the kitchen with a chisel and hammer, chipping away at the kitchen counter. Little flecks of white flew through the air like ceramic snow, landing softly on her olive-colored cheeks.
I ducked as a piece of tile flew at me. â€œHey!â€
She turned toward me with a look of surprise. â€œMorning, Izzy. I didn't see you standing there.â€
â€œWha ... what are you doing?â€ I asked.

She stepped back and surveyed the half-demolished counter the way someone stands back to study a newly hung photograph. Wiping her cheek with the back of her hand she said, â€œThere was thisâ€â€”she searched the mess on the floorâ€” â€this one broken tile poking out and I thought I should fix it and ...â€
I pushed past her to get the broom but she grabbed me by the elbow. A feeling of nervousness swelled inside me.
â€œIzzy, wait. I have something to tell you.â€
There it was. My heart buckled in my chest. Something was wrong.

Mom leaned back against the counter and sucked in a great gulp of air. â€œIt's strange actually. I wasn't expecting it, but then at the last minute the funding came through.â€ She folded her arms across her waist. â€œI'm going to Costa Rica to finish my research.â€
Her words buzzed around me like a swarm of confused bees. â€œWhen? For how long?â€
â€œI'll be gone for most of the summer. I leave Tuesday.â€
Mom wouldn't leave me. We'd go together. Right? â€œBut that's only three days away.â€ I stepped away from Mom and the shards of tile.
â€œI don't have a choice.â€
â€œBut what am I supposed to do? That's three whole months.â€
â€œTwo. I'll be home at the end of July. And after this I can finally graduate. Our lives will change then.â€ She reached over and stroked my hair. â€œFor the better.â€
I rolled those three words around in my mind: for the better.
Suddenly last night's phone call made perfect sense. I inched closer and pushed at the broken tile with my toes.
â€œAre you sending me to Nana's?â€ I asked. â€œIn New Mexico?â€
flash of surprise crossed Mom's face. Like she knew I had heard her phone conversation. â€œShe's so excited to have you and ...â€
â€œWhat happened to all your talk about you guys not seeing eye to eye?â€ I asked.
â€œIt's not that we don't see eye to eye. We just don't see the world the same way.â€
â€œWhy can't I go with you?â€ I said.
â€œIzzy ...â€

â€œNew Mexico is worlds away from California. And what am I going to do for two whole months with someone I haven't seen since I was six? That was half my life ago. She's a stranger!â€ I felt a sudden urge to bolt for the front door and run.

Mom rolled her eyes. â€œOh, Izzy. She's hardly a stranger. She's family. I already have your ticket. You leave Monday.â€ Mom opened the refrigerator and took out a diet soda, pressing the cold can against her face before opening it.
I stared at the mess on the floor. â€œWhy can't I stay here? Alone.â€ My voice quivered.
Mom took a swig of her soda, then closed her eyes and took a deep breath. When she opened them, she spoke slowly and deliberately.
â€œYou're going to New Mexico and that's final.â€
I swallowed hard and tried not to cry. â€œWhy do you always get to decide everything? We just unpacked and Iâ€”I had plans.â€
She raised her eyebrows, surprised. â€œPlans?â€

Mom was always bugging me to make friends, which I didn't see the point of, considering we moved every few months. And we moved for all sorts of reasons: closer to the university for her, better school for me, quieter, prettier, bigger, smaller.
â€œI was going to try and find some girls my age here in the complex so I wouldn't have to be the new kid in school again,â€ I said, trying to sound believable.
â€œHoney, you can make friends at your new school in the fall. Besides, this is a wonderful opportunity for you.â€
â€œOpportunity? For me? Or for you?â€
I stormed off to my room and threw myself onto my bed. I ached inside. Like the feeling you get watching a lost balloon float far into the sky until it becomes an invisible nothing.

Staring at the card, I wondered what should happen next. Maybe a daring escape or a sorceress could rescue her. When nothing came to me, I scratched out the word opportunity until it was a big blob of blue ink and tossed the card on the floor.
I heard Mom's footsteps coming toward my closed bedroom door. I held my breath, hoping she wouldn't knock.
Tap. Tap.
Silence.
â€œIzzy?â€ she spoke quietly.
My hands wandered beneath my pillow and gripped the baseball I had hidden there. I squeezed my eyes closed and whispered, â€œI wish I didn't have to go. I wish I didn't have to go.â€
â€œI've brought your suitcase.â€ She stood outside my door for what seemed like forever. I pictured her on the other side, arms crossed, head down.

â€œI think you're going to like the village.â€ Her voice became a little muffled now, like her mouth was pressed right up against the door. â€œIt's strange and beautiful at the same time and a perfect place to explore. You just might be surprised what you find there.â€ She paused for a moment then continued. â€œWould you please talk to me?â€
I burrowed my head under the pillow with the baseball. A tiny piece of me felt guilty for stealing it, but it belonged to my dad and that made it special. That made it a part of me.
â€œI'll just leave the suitcase here for you,â€ she said. Her bare feet slapped against the tile and carried her away.
